questions.text: A patient presents with heavy menstrual bleeding. Hysteroscopy was done, which revealed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Submucosal fibroid

Highyeild:

Fibroids are the most common benign solid tumours. Most common pelvic tumour. It is an estrogen and progesterone-dependent tumour. The most common age group affected is 35-45 years. Classification of fibroids: The most common presentation is menstrual disturbances. Others include – infertility, pain in the abdomen, dysmenorrhea and pressure symptoms. Investigations: USG- appears as a heterogeneous mass mostly hypoechoic, when compared with the surrounding myometrium. Diagnostic procedures - hysterography or hysteroscopy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B, and C are false.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A young lady presents to the gynaecology OPD with complaints of primary infertility, excessive weight gain and hirsutism. Laparoscopy shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PCOS

Highyeild:

Laparoscopic image shows bilateral enlarged ovaries with multiple subcapsular small follicles & increased stromal echogenicity which is seen in PCOS PCOS is the most common endocrine disorder of reproductive-age females. Features of PCOS include obesity, insulin resistance/hyperinsulinemia, acanthosis nigricans, hyperandrogenemia, anovulation, menstrual dysfunction and acne. Diagnosis criteria - Rotterdam criteria : any two of the following three criteria should be present to diagnose a patient having PCOD after excluding other etiologies. Ovulatory dysfunction such as oligomenorrhoea or amenorrhea. Clinical (hirsutism/acne/alopecia) or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism i.e. S. Testosterone between 70-150 ng/dl. Polycystic ovarian morphology on USG scan is defined as the presence of 12 or more cysts size (2-9 mm) in any one ovary or both ovaries, with enlarged ovaries (>10ml) and other criteria being excluded (like Cushing disease, adrenal hyperplasia)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and D are false.

questions.text: For the following question, there is an Assertion - (A) and Reasoning - (R) statement. Mark the correct/True option as per the following direction: Assertion - (A): Hot flushes are common after menopause Reason - (R): Hot flushes are because of low estrogen or its fluctuation Select one of the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the true/correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the true/correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the true/correct explanation for the Assertion
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the true/correct explanation for the Assertion

Highyeild:

The term "menopause" denotes the final cessation of menstruation. Clinical findings: Hot as flushes: Hot flushes (feelings of intense heat over the trunk and face, with flushing of the skin and sweating) occur in over 80% of women a result of the decrease in ovarian hormones. Vasomotor symptoms were found to last more than 7 years in more than 50% of the women. Vaginal atrophy: With decreased estrogen secretion , thinning of the vaginal mucosa and decreased vaginal lubrication occur and may lead to dyspareunia.

questions.text: Mark the following statements as true or false with respect to the indications of hormones replacement therapy after menopause: It is effective for vasomotor symptoms during the perimenopausal period It should be given to young women with premature menopause It is useful for the primary prevention of heart disease Cyclical HRT is preferred over continuous HRT in perimenopausal women

options.label: A
options.text: A. = TRUE / B. = TRUE / C. = FALSE / D. = TRUE)

options.label: B
options.text: A. = FALSE / B. = TRUE / C. = FALSE / D. = TRUE)

options.label: C
options.text: A. = TRUE / B. = TRUE / C. = TRUE / D. = TRUE)

options.label: D
options.text: A. = TRUE / B. = TRUE / C. = FALSE / D. = False)

questions.correct_answer: A. A. = TRUE / B. = TRUE / C. = FALSE / D. = TRUE)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A. = TRUE / B. = TRUE / C. = FALSE / D. = TRUE)

Highyeild:

HORMONAL REPLACEMENT THERAPY The mainstay of management / first-line treatment of vasomotor symptoms is If the uterus is removed we should receive estrogen alone, while those with intact uterus should be given estrogen + progestin (Estrogen alone will lead to endometrial hyperplasia/cancer) HRT affords no protection against cardiovascular diseases. The risk of coronary heart disease does not decrease by giving HRT. Perimenopausal women should be given cyclic HRT rather than continuous HRT. Absolute contraindications to HRT are: Acute liver disease or current gallstones disease Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding Cancer (breast/uterine) DVT

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presents with post-coital bleeding. On examination - there is the presence of cervical hypertrophy and anterior erosion with a healthy vagina. What will be the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Four-quadrant biopsy

Highyeild:

Cervical cancer is the most common gynaecological malignancy in the world . Most common age group - the bimodal peak - 1st peak seen at 35-39 years and 2nd peak 60-56 years. The most specific symptom is postcoital bleeding. Histologic reevaluation of cervical biopsy is the primary tool to diagnose cervical cancer . PAP smears are performed extensively to screen for this cancer but this test does not always detect cervical cancer. It has only 50-80 % for detecting high-grade lesions. Therefore, these lesions are directly biopsied, and biopsy is taken from the tumour periphery, as central portions often contain only necrotic tissue which fails to yield a diagnosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and C are false.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has neuro-protective action on the fetus when used in preterm birth?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MgSO4

Highyeild:

The Guideline Development Committee has noted that there is consistent evidence of benefit to the preterm baby in terms of significantly lowering the risk of cerebral palsy resulting from the use of magnesium sulfate. Although there was overall evidence of benefit when women with babies up to 34 weeks gestation were included in these trials, subgroup analysis by gestational age showed significant benefit only for babies born before 28 weeks.

questions.text: Arrange the following antenatal investigations in sequential order: Triple markers test Nuchal Translucency Scan Growth scan Anomaly scan Select the correct answer using the code below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 → 1 → 4 → 3

Highyeild:

First Trimester Screening Screening parameters are (A) Biophysical: (i) ultrasound measurement of nuchal translucency (NT), (ii) Nasal bone, (B) Biochemical: (i) free β-hCG, (ii) PAPP-A (Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein-A). Time of Test: Between 11 weeks and 14 weeks. Values: PAPP-A—reduced; β-hCG—increased; NT—measurement increased in trisomy 21. Second Trimester Screening It is done between 15 weeks and 22 weeks. Triple Tes t It is a combined biochemical test which includes MSAFP, HCG and uE3 (unconjugated estriol). It is used for the detection of Down’s syndrome . In an affected pregnancy, levels of MSAFP and uE3 tend to be low while that of HCG is high. It is performed for 15–22 weeks. It gives a risk ratio and for confirmation CVS/amniocentesis has to be done. Quadruple (Quad) Screening It includes four biochemical analytes: (1) Maternal Serum Alpha-Fetoprotein (MSAFP), (2) Unconjugated estriol (uE3), (3) dimeric inhibin-A and (4) hCG. The quad screen can detect trisomy 21. Levels of serum analytes in cases with trisomy 21: hCG—increased; uE3—reduced; inhibin A—elevated; MSAFP—reduced. Anomaly scan It is performed at 18-22 weeks. The anomaly scan allows the developing fetus to be observed in terms of morphology, bone shape, skeletal features, fetal heart function, volume evaluation, fetal lung maturity and general fetal well-being. A growth scan It is an ultrasound scan done during the last trimester of pregnancy to determine the growth of the baby.

Table:

#MANTRA Second-trimester quadruple screening Diagnosis MSAFP βB-hCG Estriol Inhibin A Trisomy 18 ⬇ ⬇ ⬇ Normal Trisomy 21 ⬇ ↑ ⬇ ↑ Neural tube or abdominal wall defect ↑ Normal Normal Normal

Highyeild:

Drugs for the Management of Immediate Postpartum Hemorrhage DRUG DOSE COMMENTS Oxytocin 20-40 units in 1 L of crystalloid initially infused at 200-500 mL/hr and then titrate to sustain uterine contractions and control hemorrhage Do not administer as an IV bolus. First-line therapy. If IV access is unavailable, may use 10 units IM Methylergonovine maleate or ergonovine maleate 0.2 mg IM Avoid in patients with hypertensive disease, including preeclampsia Carboprost tromethamine 0.25 mg IM Repeat q15min until uterine hemorrhage is controlled or a maximum dose of 2 mg Concurrent use of antiemetics and antidiarrheals recommended to control side effects Misoprostol (Cytotec) 800-1000 µg PR Single dose; can give PO. May cause tachycardia

questions.text: Which of the following types of trophoblast cells invade the spiral arterioles?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endovascular

Highyeild:

Arterial circulation: About 120–200 spiral arteries open into the intervillous space by piercing the basal plate randomly at numerous sites. Normally, there is a cytotrophoblastic invasion into the spiral arteries initially up to the intra-decidual portion within 12 weeks of pregnancy. There is a secondary invasion of trophoblast between 12 weeks and 16 weeks extending up to radial arteries within the myometrium. Spiral arteries are converted to large bore uteroplacental arteries. Trophoblast cells that do not take part in the villous structure are known as extravillous trophoblast (EVT). EVT are of two types: (i) Endovascular which migrates down the lumen of the spiral arteries and replaces the endothelium and (ii) interstitial which invades as far as the inner third of the myometrium.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false.

questions.text: A diabetic female delivers the head of the baby even after one minute the shoulder was not delivered. Which of the following is done?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

McRoberts maneuver

Highyeild:

When the delivery of the baby even after one minute the shoulder is not delivered is usually due to shoulder dystocia. Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal impacts on the maternal symphysis or the sacral promontory. Management - the following manoeuvre are commonly employed: Head and neck should be grasped and taken posteriorly while supra-pubic pressure is applied by an assistant slightly towards the side of the fetal chest. This will reduce the bis acromial diameter and rotate the anterior shoulder towards the oblique diameter. McRoberts maneuver: abduct the maternal thighs and sharply flex them onto her abdomen. There is rotation of the symphysis pubis upwards and a decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination. This does not increase pelvic dimensions but straightens the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebrae. Woods maneuver: the posterior shoulder is rotated to the anterior position (180 degrees) by a corkscrew movement. This is done by inserting two fingers in the posterior vagina. Simultaneous suprapubic pressure is applied. This pushes the bis acromial diameter from the anteroposterior diameter to an oblique diameter. This helps ease the entry of the bis acromial diameter into the pelvic inlet.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

Other techniques - Cleidotomy - one or both clavicles may be cut with scissors

questions.text: Physiological change in the respiratory system in pregnancy?

options.label: D
options.text: Total lung capacity increases by approximately 5% by term.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

FRC decreased

Highyeild:

Physiological respiratory changes in pregnancy: RV, FRC and TLC decreases Minute volume, TV and IC increases IRV, VC and RR are unchanged. Parameters Non-pregnant Pregnancy Change Respiration rate/min 15 15 Unaffected Vital capacity (mL) 3200 3300 Almost unaltered Tidal volume (mL) 475 675 Increase by 40% Residual volume (mL) 965 765 -20% Inspiratory capacity (IC) 2500 2650 Increase by 10% Minute ventilation 7.5 L/min 10.5 L/min Increase by 40% Total lung capacity (mL) 4200 4000 -5%

questions.text: Investigation of Choice for Vesico- Vaginal Fistula is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3 Swab Test

Highyeild:

3 swab test: Three separate sponge swabs are placed into the vagina one above the other. The bladder is filled with coloured agents such as methylene blue through a rubber catheter and the patient is asked to perform some exertional maneuvers and then the swabs are removed after 10mins. Interpretation Discolouration of the topmost swab or middle swab : Vesicovaginal fistula Uppermost swab wetting but not discolouration: Uretero-Vaginal fistula Discolouration of the lowermost swab but the upper two remains dry: Urethro-vaginal fistula.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 patient visits an antenatal clinic at 20 weeks. She reveals during history that her first baby weighed 4.6 kg, her second baby weighed 4.8 kg and both were delivered by C-section. The gynaecologist suspects gestational diabetes and orders a GTT. The blood sugar level after 50 gm of oral glucose is 206 mg% and the patient is thus confirmed as a case of gestational diabetes. All of the following are known complications of this condition except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fetal hyperglycemia

Highyeild:

Complications of gestational diabetes - MATERNAL During pregnancy: Abortion: Recurrent spontaneous abortion may be associated. Preterm labour Infection: Urinary tract infection and vulvovaginitis. Increased incidence of preeclampsia (25%). Polyhydramnios Diabetic retinopathy Diabetic nephropathy Coronary artery disease Ketoacidosis During labour: There is an increased incidence of Prolongation of labor. Shoulder dystocia Perineal injuries Postpartum haemorrhage Puerperium: Puerperal sepsis Lactation failure. Fetal: Fetal macrosomia with birth weight > 4 kg. CNS and skeletal: NTD, anencephaly, microcephaly, sacral agenesis Cardiac: VSD, ASD, coarctation of the aorta, transposition of great vessels Renal: Renal agenesis, hydronephrosis, ureteral duplication GIT: Duodenal atresia, anorectal atresia Others: Single umbilical artery The most common congenital malformation is congenital heart disease most common being VSD Neonatal Complications: Hypoglycemia Respiratory distress syndrome Hyperbilirubinemia Polycythemia Hypocalcemia Hypomagnesemia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are known complications.

questions.text: A pregnant lady is suffering from SLE. Which of the following autoantibodies would be responsible if her child has a congenital heart block?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti-Ro

Highyeild:

Anti-Ro (SS-A) has a prevalence of 30%. This is not specific to SLE but associated with sicca syndrome, pre-disposes to subacute cutaneous lupus and to neonatal lupus with heart block. Congenital heart block develops almost exclusively in fetuses of women with antibodies to SS-A or SS-B antigens i.e. Anti – Ro (SS-A) antibody.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and C are false.
